title: [TOPI] support dilated conv2d and depthwise_conv2d
body:
This PR allows us to compose dilated conv2d (and depthwise_conv2d) using topi.nn.dilate and topi.nn.conv2d
```python
dilated_kernel = topi.nn.dilate(kernel, (1, 1, dilation_h, dilation_w))
out = topi.nn.conv2d_nchw(data, dilated_kernel, stride, padding)
```

The definition of conv2d remains unchanged, there is still no dilation field; the schedules are updated to handle dilation. Unlike padding (SAME mode) which depends on kernel size, dilation is logically independent, so it makes sense to compose dilated conv using two separate operators.

The only tricky part is to handle dilated conv in extern libs e.g. cudnn and miopen. When using extern libs, dilation and conv will be fused into one operator. This tutorial still works with dilated conv:
https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/blob/master/tutorials/using_external_lib.py

Nick has been very active to bring secured computing to the TVM stack, notably the support of SGX runtime and other improvements to high-level nnvm and topi. He also makes good design decisions and holds a high standard for brining high-quality code to the project.

title: [RPC] Refactor, introduce tracker
body:
NOTE: This is a protocol breaking change. Please update RPC runtime, along with TVM in order for this to work

### Protocol Change in RPC
Previously, the RPC client connection will simply receive the RPC_MAGIC before it starts processing. Now it also receives the ```rpc_key``` from the server side.

### 
- support tracker that schedules the resource
   - Wee can ask server to report resource to the tracker with a given key
    ```python -m tvm.exec.rpc_server --tracker=host:port --key=device-key ```
- support server timeout

```python
from tvm.contrib import rpc

tracker = rpc.connect_tracker(url, port)
# request connection from tracker
remote = tracker.request("device-key", priority=1, session_timeout=timeout)
# same rpc code
```

cc @eqy @merrymercy

title: [WIP] Add conv2d gradients
body:
This PR enables efficient `conv2d_nchw` gradients on x86. Specifically, it
* adds an x86 schedule for `conv2d_transpose` which nets a 10x boost in performance
* adds the `conv2d_grad_weight_nchw` operator with a custom schedule for x86

Some notes:
* the method of specifying TVM tags should be made 1)  composable and 2) consistent across C++ and Python

WIP until:
- [ ] streamlined functions for all layouts via nchw converters
- [ ] add docs and other pylint necessities

This is used for [resnet](https://github.com/anokland/resnet-brelu/)

title: [SCHEDULE][PASS] Enable Warp memory and lower to shuffle
body:
This PR enables the warp memory abstraction. ```"warp"``` is a special memory scope that represents shared memory among the threads in the warp.

From the programmer's perspective, warp memory is exactly like shared memory, but it is instead lowered into local registers and its reads becomes shuffle instructions in typical GPUs. See the 

So far cuda works with a simple exmaple. to enable it for other backends

- Create a target with correct warp_size
- always set threadIdx.x's size to be warp size
- Create an intrinsic dispatching rule for tvm_warp_shuffle to dispatch to the right intrinsic

title: Fix fatal error <CL/opencl.h: No such file> when building with CMake
body:
Current CMakeLists config contains typo ("OPENCL_" instead of "OpenCL_") which leads to non-inclusion of OpenCL headers during the build, even if OpenCL was enabled with `cmake -DUSE_OPENCL=ON`.
[CMake documentation on this matter](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.1/module/FindOpenCL.html).

The fixed config was tested with AMD APP SDK 3.0 and works well.

title: Question for Unittest -- please do not merge.
body:
Hi Tianqi,
I have a question regarding the unittest in this experimental PR. 

I guess some operators of TensorSlice are illegal and should raise errors. In my local testing environment, such unittest goes all good. However, it fails here by reaching [this line](https://github.com/dingobye/tvm/blob/unittest_experiment/tests/python/unittest/test_experiment.py#L15), which means the operator in the above line is considered legal.

You know, in jerkins there are a number of runs for different settings. Such failure seems only to appear in some of those settings. Any ideas?

title: [TOPI] Overload operators of Tensor when TOPI is imported
body:
This PR solves the issue #929.

When TOPI is imported, it overloads binary operators (+, -, *, /) if at least one of the operands is Tensor. The overloaded operator performs Tensor-Tensor-broadcast operation, or Tensor-Scalar operation, wherever appropriate.

title: [RUNTIME] better parallel launcher and task distribution
body:
This PR works on two issues to improve the multi-threaded runtime performance on CPUs. 

1. Use atomic variables to coordinate the threads in `ParallelLauncher`.
2. Make `exclude_worker0` true as default, so that task 0 is run by master.
3. Bind master thread to core 0 if `exclude_worker0 == true`. The master thread is not bound when `exclude_worker0 == false`.

The overall performance boost on 18-core Intel Skylake is ~20%.

repo.name: tvm

repo.name: tvm
repo.description: Open deep learning compiler stack for cpu, gpu and specialized accelerators

title: Move BuildConfig context stack to C++
body:
The problem that this PR addresses is with porting NNVM's build function to C++. The NNVM pass `GraphFuseCompile` makes callbacks to global functions `nnvm.compiler.lower` and `nnvm.compiler.build_target` in order to invoke the TVM compiler. Both of these functions rely on being able to access the BuildConfig context, which is currently stored in python, and not available to C++.

This PR attempts to solve that by moving the context stack into C++. This requires also moving the remaining two pieces of BuildConfig state (`dump_pass_ir` and `add_lower_pass`) into the C++ node so that these aren't lost in a round trip call to get the current BuildConfig.

title: Simplify enclave lifecycle management
body:
This PR obviates the need for explicit enclave destruction steps (i.e. `ecall_shutdown` and `Shutdown()`). This will it easier to construct wrap enclaves as TVM Modules (which should be ready later today).

(turns out the issue before was that the trusted queues were being destructed rather than just closed while threads were still in them)

title: [LANGUAGE] Verify Compute with respect to Reduce operations
body:
This PR implements ComputeVerifier, which verifies the following two properties of ComputeOp:

(1) All Reduce operations must exist at top level (as described in Issue 848 ).

(2) For batch operations, if one is Reduce, then the others must be Reduce as well; and their inputs should have the same attribute except value_index. Such check was originally implemented in `ComputeOpNode::make()` and `ComputeOpNode::ReplaceInputs()`; we re-organized the code and moved it into ComputeVerifier class.

title: [BUILD] Windows build with cuDNN support
body:
TVM can build with cuDNN support on Linux system, but not on Windows.
This PR adds the option of cuDNN support on Windows.

repo.name: tvm
repo.description: Open deep learning compiler stack for cpu, gpu and specialized accelerators

title: [PASS] Add VerifyMemory pass and test cases (#410)
body:
This PR includes VerifyMemory pass to check if memory accesses are legal, along with some test cases.

As described in issue #410, in the case that tgt is cuda, if workload is not bind with threads, CPU code is generated that tries to access GPU memory, which is illegal.

This pass performs verification by inserting AssertStmt before ProducerConsumer, where memory access occurs outside of thread env (i.e. CPU code). The AssertStmt checks if device_type is CPU. If not, then CPU code is detected to access GPU memory, and a fatal is thrown.

title: Pluggable Thread Launching Mechanism
body:
Multi-threaded TVM in SGX.

Basically the idea is:
1. configure a thread pool in the untrusted environment w/ `num_threads` and target `enclave_id`
2. when a job is launched, place the tasks in the trusted thread queues
3. start the untrusted thread pool, which has threads enter the enclave and start popping tasks off their respective queues
4. join the tasks in the enclave
5. join the untrusted thread pool

The WIP is because I haven't yet tested this with NNVM workloads.

title: [PASS] fix buffer overlap when reuse small buffers
body:
fix overlap issue in #942 
for case in this patch, the ir after pass is 
```
// attr [A] storage_scope = "local.L0A"
allocate A[int16 * 800]
for (i, 0, n) {
  for (j, 0, 10) {
    A[j] = (int16)1
    A[(200 + j)] = (int16)1
    A[j] = (A[j] + A[(200 + j)])
    A[j] = (int16)1
    A[(400 + j)] = (int16)1
    A[j] = A[j]
    A[j] = (int16)1
    A[(200 + j)] = (int16)1
    A[j] = (A[j] + A[(200 + j)])
  }
}
```
